\[d_1^2 + d_2^2 + d_3^2 = 36.\]Find the region of the volume enclosed by $S.$

Give reasons why any other choice would not work.

direct_answer.text:

Therefore, our new problem asks us what portion of space outside the rectangular solid bounded by x=±2, −z=±2 ,and x−2y=-2 lies inside S.
To start analyzing things geometrically, note firstly that any line passing through (-2,0,0) and parallel to say jaw i will pass through exactly five lattice points within [-2,2], corresponding to those whose argument modulo pi/2 belongs to {pi/6, pi/3} . Similarly, every segment joining the origin and some other lattice point also passes either via four more intermediate lattice points belonging to arguments equivalent modulo pi/4, or else merely via six non-intermediate ones belonging to angles equal to multiples of pi/6. As a consequence, when viewed along direction k, the projection bounds lie precisely at [–π/2, –π/3]∪[π/3, π/2]. 0.user_question:
For a point $P,$ let $d_1,$ $d_2$ and $d_3$ represents the distances from $P$ to the planes $x - z = 0,$ $x - 2y + z = 0,$ and $x + y + z = 0.$  Let $S$ be the set of points $P$ such that
\[d_1^2 + d_2^2 + d_3^2 = 36.\]Find the region of the volume enclosed by $S.$

ost_step.1: Notice that each equation describes a plane passing through three axes ($x=0$, $y=0$, or $z=0$). Each pair of equations intersect along a line. For example, when looking at $x - z = 0$ and $x + y + z = 0,$ solve them simultaneously; we get $y=-1/2 x$ while satisfying both requirements as long as $x=t, y=-1/2 t, z=t$ so any point lying on one side of said intersection lines satisfies those two constraints. Similarly analyze other pairs too likewise you obtain six intersections forming a hexagon whose vertices lie either exactly within one constraint but not another, e.g., $(0, 0, 0)$, $(\pm 2,\mp 2, \pm 2)$, etc. It turns out that every vertex lies inside S except possibly four opposite ones due to symmetry about origin. Now notice it does NOT matter whether our coordinate system starts off centered around origin since adding some vector results in same problem just shifted over! Hence without loss generality consider first quadrant hereafter... And now imagine cutting up square into small unit cells having sides parallel edges equal length s called voxels because volumes sound cool

0.user_question:
For a point $P,$ let $d_1,$ $d_2$ and $d_3$ represents the distances from $P$ to the planes $x - z = 0,$ $x - 2y + z = 0,$ and $x + y + z = 0.$  Let $S$ be the set of points $P$ such that
\[d_1^2 + d_2^2 + d_3^2 = 36.\]Find the region of the volume enclosed by $S.$

direct_answer.text:
We know each equation corresponds to one coordinate axis; hence it projects onto the three axes as shown below.

Therefore, our new problem asks us what portion of space outside the rectangular solid bounded by x=±2, −z=±2 ,and x−2y=-2 lies inside S.
To start analyzing things geometrically, note firstly that any line passing through (-2,0,0) and parallel to say jaw i will pass through exactly five lattice points within [-2,2], corresponding to those whose argument modulo pi/2 belongs to {pi/6, pi/3} . Similarly, every segment joining the origin and some other lattice point also passes either via four more intermediate lattice points belonging to arguments equivalent modulo pi/4, or else merely via six non-intermediate ones belonging to angles equal to multiples of pi/6. As a consequence, when viewed along direction k, the projection bounds lie precisely at [–π/2, –π/3]∪[π/3, π/2].
